TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit WebClientAsyncResult extends System.Object implements class System.IAsyncResult

Docs.summary: Provides an implementation of for use by XML Web service proxies to implement the standard asynchronous method pattern.

remarks.format:
## Remarks When you call the `BeginMyMethodName` method, where `MyMethodName` is the synchronous version of the method, on an XML Web service proxy class, an instance of the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.WebClientAsyncResult> is returned. Following the standard asynchronous design pattern, that instance of <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.WebClientAsyncResult> must later be passed to `EndMyMethodName` to complete the asynchronous method call.
For details on calling XML Web services asynchronously, see [Communicating with XML Web Services Asynchronously](https://docs.microsoft.com/previous-versions/dotnet/netframework-4.0/tz4bkcx2(v=vs.100)).

Docs.related: Communicating with XML Web Services Asynchronously

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Abort() cil managed

Docs.summary: Cancels an asynchronous XML Web service request.

remarks.format: ## Examples The XML Web service request is canceled if the underlying transport supports the <xref:System.Net.WebRequest.Abort%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. If the corresponding `End` method is subsequently called after the <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.WebClientAsyncResult.Abort%2A> method, a <xref:System.Net.WebException> is thrown, setting the <xref:System.Net.WebException.Status%2A> property to <xref:System.Net.WebExceptionStatus.RequestCanceled>.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property AsyncState As Object
public: property System::Object ^ AsyncState { System::Object ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets the object provided in the last parameter to the method asynchronous call.
Docs.value: The provided in the last parameter to the method call.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property AsyncWaitHandle As WaitHandle
public: property System::Threading::WaitHandle ^ AsyncWaitHandle { System::Threading::WaitHandle ^ get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a that is used to wait for an asynchronous operation to complete.
Docs.value: A that is used to wait for an asynchronous operation to complete.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Threading.WaitHandle> can be used to perform a <xref:System.Threading.WaitHandle.WaitOne%2A>, <xref:System.Threading.WaitHandle.WaitAny%2A>, or <xref:System.Threading.WaitHandle.WaitAll%2A> to wait for the asynchronous call to complete.
For more details, see <xref:System.IAsyncResult.AsyncWaitHandle%2A>.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property CompletedSynchronously As Boolean
public: property bool CompletedSynchronously { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the Begin call completed synchronously.
Docs.value: if the Begin call completed synchronously; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks If <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.WebClientAsyncResult.CompletedSynchronously%2A> is set to `true` within the <xref:System.AsyncCallback> delegate, it is probable that the thread that called <xref:System.Web.Services.Protocols.SoapHttpClientProtocol.BeginInvoke%2A> is the current thread. In this case, you should be careful about making another asynchronous Begin call from the callback method, since it can cause the stack to grow without bound if the calls continue to complete synchronously. Instead, the call should be completed at the original call site, outside the callback method.

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsCompleted As Boolean
public: property bool IsCompleted { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the asynchronous XML Web service request has completed.
Docs.value: if the asynchronous XML Web service request has completed; otherwise, .
